Comment: Banks do make money off fee income from customers using their services. They also use your money to loan out making higher income on interest received than paid out, called the spread. However they must keep a certain amount of money in reserve to pay out depositors should they demand their money. They must pay into the FDIC insurance fund to insure your money, its a delicate balance. In the 1980's there was a lot of deregulation of how banks could invest their money which was partially responsible 2008 financial crisis. Another law was passed 2010 to regulate banks, how they could invest and how much money they needed to keep in reserves. In 2017 Trump signed bill into law that substantially weakened the 2010 law and allowed banks to make more risky decisions on what they did with depositors money which some say was the reason SVB got into trouble.  If you want more information on the above this is an excellent article: https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/dodd-frank-act/

Comment: Credit unions don't have "customers"; they have "members".  (Similarly, they have "share accounts" instead of savings accounts and "share draft accounts" instead of checking accounts.)  Because depositing money in a credit union *is* buying part ownership in the credit union, and entitles you to vote for its directors.  Banks, OTOH, are usually owned by stockholders who may or may not have any accounts at the bank.  This can create disparate financial incentives between depositors and stockholders.
